node.text:
.
Believe it or not, I HAVE DONE SEVEN SOCIAL THINGS since my move to California. This is THREE MORE SOCIAL THINGS than I did in all of my years in Florida.
 
Here is the magic I have discovered that is allowing me to make plans: ENDING TIMES.
 
Our first week in Cali, we got an invitation to a thing that said: “Come over. We're having a little party. And it’s from 5 to 8.” 
 
WHATTTTT THE WHATTTTT? We can agree ahead of time that our hangout will end at a specific time??? I will know—when I leave my couch—exactly what time I will return to my couch???? Without spending the entire time I’m there planning my exit strategy??? WHAT FRESH HEAVEN IS THIS???
 
YOU HAVE PERMISSION TO TELL PEOPLE WHEN THEY SHOULD LEAVE. TELL THEM! They will be so grateful!! Leaving Anxiety FREEDOM!!!
 
In addition to that particular epiphany: Today on We Can Do Hard Things, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I are continuing our conversation about Sexual Desire. COME HANG OUT WITH US. IT WILL BE OVER IN FORTY SEVEN MINUTES AND FIFTY NINE SECONDS.
 
Buckle up, Loves! Listen at the link in my bio.
G

node.text:
.
Greetings from your resident SILENT SEX QUEEN! Today on We Can Do Hard Things, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I are talking about Sexual Desire. 
 
We’re not talking about the eating of the cupcake—but the hunger that compels us to pick a certain flavor.  About what turns us on and off, and how labels can cause us to completely stop exploring our own desire. 
 
We also explore: 
1️⃣ How Abby discovered her gayness while out to dinner with her parents at a Macaroni Grill. 
2️⃣ The moment I knew for sure I was queer (in a Boogie Nights bathroom)—and the song that sealed the deal. 
3️⃣ How, as a straight, cis woman, Amanda never had to wrestle with her sexuality, and why she thinks that stunted her exploration.
4️⃣ How my failed Van Gogh visit inspired Amanda’s next sex steps. 

This one is not to be missed, friends. Listen at the link in my bio.

LYLASSS (silent sex queen),
G

node.text:
Tomorrow - Unbound by Tarana Burke releases. This book is a piece of timeless art- a modern classic. It will go down as one of the great memoirs.

Dearest @taranajaneen, What you have done with Unbound is stunning. My mouth hung open at least once on every page. You have done your little girl self proud. Unbound will heal hearts, destroy shame, free survivors. You have became who you needed when you were younger- and that has changed the entire world for girls and women. I don't know anybody braver. 
Tomorrow, may the world you have loved so fiercely, love you back. May you be handled warmly. May there be air.

node.text:
.
Somewhere along the way, our parenting generation decided it was our job and responsibility to protect our children from experiencing pain and heartbreak. Like it was our duty to mow down anything in their path that could make them feel sad or lonely or angry or left out. 

We are breaking ourselves with an utterly impossible task, and at the same time, we’re robbing our kids of the one thing that will allow them to become the brave, kind, and wise adults that we hope they’ll become. 

Our job is not to run in front of our children, putting out every single fire over and over again, behind them and around them, at soccer practice and at school and in friends groups. Our job is just to notice the fires ahead with them, walk them toward and through, over and over again. 

Because we want them to be able to do that when we’re gone. 

But, as Amanda says in today’s episode: It is much easier said than done.

Listen at the link in my bio.
G

node.text:
.
The world is an utter avalanche of heartbreak—and at times, so are our personal lives. 
 
We recorded this episode two days before we left Chase at college, so…good luck. I did my best. 

Am I okay? NOPE. 
Is that okay? YEP.
 
Today on We Can Do Hard Things, we’re asking:  How do we feel hard feelings without being consumed by them? How do we experience emotions—not as good or bad—but simply as helpful guides pointing us toward information about ourselves and our environments?
 
WE DON’T KNOW. But Amanda walks us through two strategies proven to help. I promise to try to try her strategies ANOTHER TIME because right now I’m committed to my usual strategies: reading my feelings and eating my feelings. I’ve got a 5-pound tub of red vines and a stack of books three feet high, and I LIKE MY STRATEGIES.

If you are FEELING IT ALL right now, come settle in with us. You, me, Amanda, and @AbbyWambach will feel it all together. 

Let us know. What’s breaking your heart right now?  What are your coping strategies and are they better than red vines?

Listen at the link in my bio.
G

node.text:
.
On yesterday’s We Can Do Hard Things podcast, I share my best advice for how to communicate with highly-sensitive, upset kiddos. And, in this moment in which everything feels so awful, so overwhelming, so hard, I think it may be helpful for us to use with ourselves, too.  

So, here’s what we are going to do when those big, hard feelings come—for us, or for our little ones:

We aren’t going to try to fix those feelings. We are going to stop trying to fix, and instead start meeting them exactly where they are. All we have to do is make them feel seen. Instead of explaining away, minimizing, or rationalizing—we will AGREE with them that this thing that is happening is the worst thing that has ever happened and that they have every right to be devastated. 

(It works for me only every single time.)

In this week’s second episode of We Can Do Hard Things, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I continue talking about talking: 

1️⃣ Amanda has a Ted Lasso moment, presenting a case for “summer rain” love—and rejecting “lightning love” as the highest form of romantic love. 
2️⃣ I offer ideas about how to know when to speak up or shut up.
3️⃣ Abby shares her experience in a mostly-male meeting that proved “silent solidarity” is a cowardly lie. 

Listen at the link in my bio.
G

node.text:
.
When I go out into the world, it feels like everyone is talking and nobody is listening to each other ever. It feels like most “conversations” are just endless cycles of people interrupting each other, one-upping each other, waiting to talk without listening, or creating monologue hostage situations. It feels like such a WASTE.

Conversation is the tool we have to connect—to feel less alone. But nobody really teaches us how to use our tool. I think that could be why we're so lonely: Because we don't even really know how to use the one tool we have to connect with each other.  

So, today, on We Can Do Hard Things, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I are talking about talking—and how we can begin to use conversation as a key to unlocking each other. 

*Interrupting is my Conversation Pet Peeve. It takes my anxiety through the roof. I know some of you disagree completely: What feels destructive to me feels constructive and creative to you. 

WHAT’S YOUR CONVERSATION PET PEEVE?

WHAT MAKES YOU FEEL MOST CONNECTED AND HEARD IN CONVERSATIONS?

WHO DO YOU LOVE TO TALK TO THE MOST? WHY?

Listen at the link in my bio. 
G

node.text:
.
This week on the We Can Do Hard Things pod, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I are discussing how culture’s invention of gender is the lens through which the world sees and reacts to us, including Amanda’s observation:

“I'm very direct, confident, assertive, and effective in my job roles. In other words, if I were a man, I would be what you would call a very successful businessman. But since I am not a man, even though I lead us in attaining really good business results, I am constantly being labeled as a lot or difficult to work with or aggressive.”

We also discuss:
1️⃣ Abby’s experiences of being publicly misgendered—and how that makes her feel.
2️⃣ Why is gender the last place we’ve agreed it’s acceptable to make identity assumptions?
3️⃣ Why do we tell people who they are before they’re even born—and a thousand different ways every day after?
4️⃣ Why Glennon says two women in a marriage, handling their own business, rocks the patriarchal boat. 

How do gender assumptions affect how people see you and react to you?

Listen at the link in my bio.

Love,
G

node.text:
.
Today on We Can Do Hard Things, we’re going to get to know Amanda a little better. 

Some people like to roller skate for fun. Amanda likes studying gender and power dynamics. As you’re listening to this conversation, you’ll understand that all of the themes that we explore in the podcast, in @Together.Rising’s work, and in UNTAMED—themes of women and power structures—have always been informed by my sister’s knowledge and passion. 

She is the lens that helps us see: We are not crazy. We’re cheetahs the world has tried to cage.

I love my sister, Amanda. And I’m so happy you do, too.

Listen at the link in my bio.
G

P.S. She’s also really freaking funny. In this clip, we consider: WHY IS IT THAT HALF THE POPULATION LOOKS AT THEIR FACES AND THINKS “I’M GOOD” AND THE OTHER HALF LOOKS AT OUR FACES AND THINKS “NOT GOOD ENOUGH.”

node.text:
.
We can do hard things. But do we need to do them ALL THE TIME?

In today’s episode, we try easier.  We talk about:
1️⃣ My radical acceptance that I’m always going to be a midnight person in a sunshine world.
2️⃣ Our favorite movies and music—and what they reveal about our personalities.
3️⃣ Why @abbywambach is objectively hot, but please don’t tell me that at parties.

Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
.
Today, on We Can Do Hard Things, we’re discussing the power of quitting as an act of self-love, freedom, and survival. 

We recorded this episode before Simone Biles stepped away from an Olympic moment to protect her own mental, physical, and emotional health. Judging by the world’s reaction to her NO heard ‘round the world—we think we were onto something with this convo. Because the world loses its damn mind when a woman, especially a Black woman, decides to abandon the world's expectations of her instead of abandoning herself.

In this conversation, I go toe-to-toe with two of the biggest non-quitters I know: Abby Wambach and my sister, Amanda Doyle. 

We discuss how to know when it’s time to let something or someone go. Perhaps we have to ask: Do I want to become free of this thing because this thing is hard for me—or do I want to become free of this thing because it’s NOT for me?

We can quit hard things! Let’s go!

Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
.
If you’ve listened to our Tuesday episode of We Can Do Hard Things, you understand why it was so important to me to Untame my sex life. I want us all to begin to experience sex as a place where we please and honor ourselves, not just our partners. When we do that, sex becomes real.
 
Today, we answer your Sexy Qs, Say Farewell to Faking It, and Vouch for Vibrators. 
 
Also: Amanda talks through how 75% of women can better set themselves up for success in the bedroom; we discuss detoxing from religious purity / sex shame culture; raising kids with a healthier relationship to sex; and the one sex subject that’s a hard no for Abby and me.
 
Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
.
Believe it or not, I HAVE DONE SEVEN SOCIAL THINGS since my move to California. This is THREE MORE SOCIAL THINGS than I did in all of my years in Florida.
 
Here is the magic I have discovered that is allowing me to make plans: ENDING TIMES.
 
Our first week in Cali, we got an invitation to a thing that said: “Come over. We're having a little party. And it’s from 5 to 8.” 
 
WHATTTTT THE WHATTTTT? We can agree ahead of time that our hangout will end at a specific time??? I will know—when I leave my couch—exactly what time I will return to my couch???? Without spending the entire time I’m there planning my exit strategy??? WHAT FRESH HEAVEN IS THIS???
 
YOU HAVE PERMISSION TO TELL PEOPLE WHEN THEY SHOULD LEAVE. TELL THEM! They will be so grateful!! Leaving Anxiety FREEDOM!!!
 
In addition to that particular epiphany: Today on We Can Do Hard Things, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I are continuing our conversation about Sexual Desire. COME HANG OUT WITH US. IT WILL BE OVER IN FORTY SEVEN MINUTES AND FIFTY NINE SECONDS.
 
Buckle up, Loves! Listen at the link in my bio.
G

node.text:
And to ALY AND MAGGIE.
And to you- you who were hurt, who were not seen, protected, valued, believed, saved- you deserved to be. There was a grave error in the world- not within you. You are perfect. 
You were always perfect. 
You are loved.
You are beloved.
You are love.

May mighty forces rush to your side and protect you while you heal forever. 

While you heal, we will fight. 

Love, Fury, Relentless Hope,
G

node.text:
Mackayla is fighting for her life while caring for her newborn baby. Through @together.rising, all of us—this community—provided the financial support that is allowing her to focus on what she needs to: her treatment and her little girl.

Mackayla was first diagnosed with laryngeal cancer while pregnant. Stage four. Her precious baby daughter, Avery, was born just five months ago. Over those five months, Mackayla has been traveling from Maine to Massachusetts for treatment. Her mom, Carrie, took an unpaid leave of absence from her job to travel with and help care for Mackayla and Avery. Together, Carrie and Mackayla have been driving back and forth, back and forth—eight hundred miles roundtrip.

In May, Mackayla endured surgery to remove her larynx. Her ability to speak has been significantly impacted. It may never be the same again.

While Mackayla has been in treatment, her fiancé, Raymond, has had to stay in Maine. We know the first several months after a new baby’s arrival can be both a huge adjustment period and a very special time for new parents. We cannot imagine how especially difficult it has been for this family to not only have Mackayla fighting for her life but be forced to be apart while she does.

On top of the cancer diagnosis and the radiation and the surgery and the travel and the new baby, the family also lost Raymond’s dad recently. Right before Avery was born.

When Raymond’s aunt, Missy, wrote to us, our hearts cracked wide open. She asked if @Together.Rising would support Mackayla and her family. We said of course we will—Together Rising exists to be a place to turn. Together, all of us lifted this young mom by sending her a grant to cover unpaid treatment costs, travel, diapers, formula, food, housing, and more. With our support, Mackayla is focusing not on bills but on her treatment and her baby girl.

Mackayla, thank you for allowing us to show up for you, for Carrie, for Missy, for Raymond, and for little Avery. To this wonderful community, thank you for continuing to trust deeply and invest wholeheartedly in us. Your support is what enables @together.rising to be a place where families like Mackayla’s can turn.

node.text:
Thank you, California, thank you.

Thanks for this image Annie Galvin @3fishstudios (love them!!!) Via  @karlawelchstylist - this is EXACTLY how I feel right now. 
I'll be pissed about the ridiculous waste of funds on the recall tomorrow. Tonight: relief, softness, a deep breath and gratitude for my home state.

node.text:
.
Greetings from your resident SILENT SEX QUEEN! Today on We Can Do Hard Things, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I are talking about Sexual Desire. 
 
We’re not talking about the eating of the cupcake—but the hunger that compels us to pick a certain flavor.  About what turns us on and off, and how labels can cause us to completely stop exploring our own desire. 
 
We also explore: 
1️⃣ How Abby discovered her gayness while out to dinner with her parents at a Macaroni Grill. 
2️⃣ The moment I knew for sure I was queer (in a Boogie Nights bathroom)—and the song that sealed the deal. 
3️⃣ How, as a straight, cis woman, Amanda never had to wrestle with her sexuality, and why she thinks that stunted her exploration.
4️⃣ How my failed Van Gogh visit inspired Amanda’s next sex steps. 

This one is not to be missed, friends. Listen at the link in my bio.

LYLASSS (silent sex queen),
G

node.text:
Tomorrow - Unbound by Tarana Burke releases. This book is a piece of timeless art- a modern classic. It will go down as one of the great memoirs.

Dearest @taranajaneen, What you have done with Unbound is stunning. My mouth hung open at least once on every page. You have done your little girl self proud. Unbound will heal hearts, destroy shame, free survivors. You have became who you needed when you were younger- and that has changed the entire world for girls and women. I don't know anybody braver. 
Tomorrow, may the world you have loved so fiercely, love you back. May you be handled warmly. May there be air.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glennon Doyle on September 12, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
1. This is me trying.
2. Thank you to the birthday girl, @karlawelchstylist for letting me borrow this dress for a thing I was nervous about. You are good and generous and I respect what you're doing for women and the earth with @theperiodcompany.
3. An hour of makeup done by a professional made my face look like this. I just think it's important to note. Swipe to see what my sweet face looks like where I am right now- on the soccer sideline- because this is where I live and where I'll die. My tombstone will say: GOOD HUSTLE. I like my face both ways but the older I get, the more I like it naked best.
4. Life is hard but I hope you're finding some rest and joy today. 
Love, G

node.text:
.
Somewhere along the way, our parenting generation decided it was our job and responsibility to protect our children from experiencing pain and heartbreak. Like it was our duty to mow down anything in their path that could make them feel sad or lonely or angry or left out. 

We are breaking ourselves with an utterly impossible task, and at the same time, we’re robbing our kids of the one thing that will allow them to become the brave, kind, and wise adults that we hope they’ll become. 

Our job is not to run in front of our children, putting out every single fire over and over again, behind them and around them, at soccer practice and at school and in friends groups. Our job is just to notice the fires ahead with them, walk them toward and through, over and over again. 

Because we want them to be able to do that when we’re gone. 

But, as Amanda says in today’s episode: It is much easier said than done.

Listen at the link in my bio.
G

node.text:
.
The world is an utter avalanche of heartbreak—and at times, so are our personal lives. 
 
We recorded this episode two days before we left Chase at college, so…good luck. I did my best. 

Am I okay? NOPE. 
Is that okay? YEP.
 
Today on We Can Do Hard Things, we’re asking:  How do we feel hard feelings without being consumed by them? How do we experience emotions—not as good or bad—but simply as helpful guides pointing us toward information about ourselves and our environments?
 
WE DON’T KNOW. But Amanda walks us through two strategies proven to help. I promise to try to try her strategies ANOTHER TIME because right now I’m committed to my usual strategies: reading my feelings and eating my feelings. I’ve got a 5-pound tub of red vines and a stack of books three feet high, and I LIKE MY STRATEGIES.

If you are FEELING IT ALL right now, come settle in with us. You, me, Amanda, and @AbbyWambach will feel it all together. 

Let us know. What’s breaking your heart right now?  What are your coping strategies and are they better than red vines?

Listen at the link in my bio.
G

node.text:
The world feels overwhelming right now. Unbelievably so. When it all feels like too much, we focus on doing the next right thing. Today, the next right thing for @Together.Rising is supporting Afghan families who have arrived in the U.S. through a $300,000 investment that will provide critically-needed housing, food, clothing, and other basic necessities.
 
As of Wednesday, more than 23,000 Afghan people have arrived at military bases in Virginia, Wisconsin, New Mexico, Texas, and New Jersey. Most of them have nothing but the clothes they are wearing. They’ve been forced from their homes and everything they’ve known. Now is our chance to hold them close, to welcome them with open arms.
 
Many refugees and Special Immigrant Visa holders are undergoing the next step in the resettlement process, which is to get connected to one of nine resettlement organizations that UNHCR partners with. The organizations we are investing in—@ecdc.us and @lirsorg—are among those deeply respected in this space. Their teams provide culturally sensitive, comprehensive support.
Together, they have successfully resettled more than 550,000 refugees. 
 
@Together.Rising is investing $300,000 in LIRS and ECDC to enable their teams to welcome each family and work hand-in-hand with them to ensure they have critically-needed housing, food, clothing, and basic necessities.
 
Even as we make this investment now, we know that these same families will need long-term support, that thousands more are set to arrive in the coming weeks, and that millions still in Afghanistan are in crisis.
 
Our team is listening intently to Afghan voices and actively assessing and thoroughly vetting the best ways for @Together.Rising to help on as many fronts of this crisis as possible.
 
Today, this second deployment of funds is the next right thing for our commitment to Afghan women, children, and families.
 
Thank you to every person who has already donated to help these families. If you are in a position to do so, please consider supporting this ongoing effort by donating at the link in our my or by clicking “Donate to Afghanistan” at TogetherRising.org/Give.
